posts.name: Addie Zimmerman
posts.cooked:
Assume that, hypothetically, someone on your team doesnâ€™t know anything about electrical, but wants to learn. Unfortunately, they find the subject a bit daunting and donâ€™t really know where to start. Do any of you have any good tips, resources, or anything of the like that someone (not me) can use to get well-versed in electrical before the season starts? Any help is greatly appreciated!

posts.name: Marc Antinossi
posts.cooked: The documentation in the WPI library helped me build a good foundation to my still limited electrical knowledge. The documentation for the FIRST Robotics Competition provides a brief overview of the hardware components that make up the FRC Â® Control System. Each component is described in detail. Additionally, the Introduction to FRC Robot Wiring offers a detailed diagram of all components and how they are connected. Between these two links, one should be able to fairly quickly design a controls system and wire their robot.

posts.name: Mansour Mohamed
posts.cooked: CD is a valuable resource because it lets you view various issues teams face and their solutions. For learning the basics of FRC electrical, consider these options: FRC Zero, Spectrum's training resources, and Citrus's training materials. These are excellent for mastering wiring robots and fixing issues that come up.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked: These were very helpful and taught me most of what I needed to know. If you have access to a robot, wiring a CAN loop really helped me learn where all of the components were and was a relatively easy way to get a basis for electrical.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: These are 2491's electrical documentation. Access the document via Google Drive at [this link](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HbCdLzyGGJwBivJxYNCFDymWmuhM6Nb7NL74Bqe5O-I/edit?usp=drivesdk). The document details "Wiring Pattern language," covering essential topics like achieving wiring credentials, basic skills such as crimping, labeling methods, wire management, routing, bundling, and zip ties.

posts.name: David Swed

IMPORTANTLY DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION) JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH
The text is:
In my opinion the most important part of doing electrical is just making sure it doesnâ€™t break during a match Made a presentation last year on the most common failures and how to prevent them https docs google com presentation d 1DtPFvJv64e6FymtbhhrVlMp6roh0l_S5xkROfEUnYfg edit uspd drivesdk
TLDR
â€¢ Secure your batteries with a metal frame in all dimensions
â€¢ Make sure your team has a battery beak and knows how to test batteries before every match
â€¢ Strain relief every single connection point if you tug on a wire it should tug on a zip tie and not the actual connection
â€¢ solder your CAN bus and put heat shrink on your connections Trust me just do it itâ€™s the worst thing to trouble shoot

posts.cooked: 3414 focused heavily into guides for crimping as the most common failure point. However, our own docs do include a lot of other more general things that should be checked out. We also link to other resources we used and think would be helpful for others.

posts.name: Brennan Macaig
posts.cooked:
Electrical work in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) is a challenging topic due to its reliance on opinion and knowledge. The electrical systems in FRC are highly specific, and the components involved are typically not found outside FRC environments. Unlike tools like OnShape or Java, new students and mentors may lack experience with advanced electrical components beyond basic wiring.

For example, recommendations vary widely for soldering CAN (Controller Area Network) wiringâ€”some advise soldering, while others suggest avoiding it. This variability can be overwhelming for newcomers seeking a starting point.

To begin, focus on understanding the components and their functions. Start with foundational knowledge, such as reading WPILib resources on wiring or consulting the game manual for diagrams and guidance. Once you grasp what each component does and how it operates, delve deeper into FRC electrical systems.

Critical power paths, as noted by JamesCH95, include:
1. Battery terminals
2. Main breaker terminals
3. Battery negative and main breaker to PDH/PDP
4. PDH/PDP to roboRIO
5. PDH/PDP to robot radio, including POE injectors
6. roboRIO to robot radio via Ethernet

Failures in these areas can lead to robots disconnecting from the Field Management System (FMS), potentially causing downtime ranging from seconds to minutes depending on the issue.

Additional tips from JamesCH95 include:
1. Always address the root cause of brownout issues, often related to loose wires on batteries or main breakers
2. Prioritize clear, visible wiring; ideally, wires should be traceable without tools
3. Standardize on connectors (e.g., Anderson, molexSL, wago levernuts) for specific tasks
4. Allow extra length in wiring to accommodate obstacles; plan accordingly

Lastly, remember that brownout symptoms, like "stuttering," indicate wiring issues. Neat connections and redundancy are key to robust designs.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: Stop your programming team from getting angry at you by ensuring they understand your work and respect their expertise. Always check your work thoroughly. When working with CAN bus systems, ensure the REV client/tuner can see all CAN messages properly. Test motors after wiring by running them in the appropriate CAN tool if available, verifying they function as intended. Confirm sensor responses match expectations, test connections by physically pulling wires to ensure stability. Regularly verify everything works as expected.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
The controls students often struggle to effectively troubleshoot controls failures because they lack understanding of how the devices they use function, how they communicate, or how to utilize their diagnostic tools.  

If you aim to become a top-tier controls student, continue learning beyond basic concepts. Focus on mastering diagnostic tools such as Rev Hardware client or Phoenix Tuner, and pay attention to sensor requirements specific to programming. Additionally, be mindful of aspects like field of view on rangefinders to avoid obstructions and ensure switches operate as intended. Understanding physical interfaces required by programming, including motor controller USB ports, can help prevent future issues.  

A competent controls student ensures functionality through blinking upon power-on but strives to create a reliable system ready for transfer to coders and maintainability when problems arise. While this may not be a traditional controls course, for returning students, approaching it with an eye toward applying hardware knowledge could prove beneficial. Start with getting started guides focusing on physical interfaces, plugs, and diagnostics.

posts.name: Shoumik | 8866 | Driver
posts.cooked: I love LYNK's Library of Knowledge as a good library of resources from top teams like 1678 and 3847 for an introduction into the basics of FRC Electrical. Definitely helped with teaching new members the overall basics before diving into what we do specifically as a team (connectors, practices, etc). Also, I think that the Unofficial FRC Discord is an underrated source of knowledge. I would attribute the electrical channel in the server as one of best resources that drastically increased my knowledge and the quality of our electrical. What I personally did was scroll through some messages to figure out who talked the most (Banks, Nick, Peter, and Daltz are a few people who come to mind) and then searched all the messages that person sent in the channel. I just read through a few hundred messages each day last summer, which really helped me get a better understanding, especially because the people that I listed talk a lot in that channel to help people, so you gain a lot of insight on how to diagnose common electrical issues. Iâ€™d also recommend asking questions in that channel (since one of those people I listed is a mentor for a team in Peachtree District, I personally asked questions through the district-specific server, but the Unofficial Discord is great for asking questions in). You sometimes get ignored but just wait a bit and resend your message, though donâ€™t repeatedly repost your message like every 5 minutes. LYNK Library of Knowledge has more info about Electrical at [link].

I canâ€™t help you with electrical. But I did just want to say that you shouldnâ€™t self-deprecate because you do not know something. That doesnâ€™t make you a dummy; if you were a dummy you would not have asked to learn more. Itâ€™s also okay to not know something and you donâ€™t need to be afraid to admit it.

Sure! Hereâ€™s the cleaned-up version based on your instructions:

Bro beat me to my own resource. But yeah, the LLK is full of stuff and I constantly update it. I'm also working on a paper on how LYNK builds their robots robustly (including Electrical stuff).

A highly recommended practice involves wiring a robot, such as a practice bot or rewiring an off-season bot, before the competition season begins. Learning through reading alone often falls short, and your first attempt may result in unintended mistakes, especially on the competition robot.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Important lesson: avoid using tools like sledgehammers in the oilfield.

Connectors are the most common points of failure; eliminate them if possible.

Pressure washers can enter sealed electrical boxes; by forcing a 90-degree turn, you can make them stay dry.

Potting components in plain epoxy is bad; it causes chip formation and capacitor damage. Instead, seal around large chips and incorporate micro-balloons for better results and cost savings.

Hardware store silicone is bad for electronics due to its acetic acid content; opt for electronic-grade silicone instead.

Avoid using zinc chloride flux unless necessary for soldering to stainless steel or nichrome wire; always clean afterward and keep it away from children.

posts.name: philso

Here's the cleaned-up version of the text, preserving the original meaning while ensuring clarity and proper formatting:

---

The text is in the Orlando FL area. After reviewing available resources, it would be beneficial to reach out to established teams in your region for in-person learning, as teaching effective techniques in this manner can be more efficient. Prioritize teams with reliable control systems that demonstrate organization, avoiding those resembling disorganized structures ("bowls of spaghetti"). Additionally, consider including teammates who show a strong commitment to detail and meticulousness in their work, as this can foster better habits when learning complex systems.

---
